sect1.title: Introduction
sect1.para: &app; enables you to create the following types of simple dialog:

listitem.para: Calendar
File selection
List
Notification icon
Message
Error
Information
Question
Warning
Progress
Text entry
Text information

sect1.title: Usage
sect1.para: When you write scripts, you can use &app; to create simple dialogs that interact graphically with the user, as follows:

listitem.para: You can create a dialog to obtain information from the user. For example, you can prompt the user to select a date from a calendar dialog, or to select a file from a file selection dialog.

You can create a dialog to provide the user with information. For example, you can use a progress dialog to indicate the current status of an operation, or use a warning message dialog to alert the user.

sect1.para: When the user closes the dialog, &app; prints the text produced by the dialog to standard output.

note.para: When you write &app; commands, ensure that you place quotation marks around each argument.
For example, use: matedialog --calendar --title="Holiday Planner" Do not use: matedialog --calendar --title=Holiday Planner
If you do not use quotation marks, you might get unexpected results.

sect2.title: Access Keys
sect2.para: An access key is a key that enables you to perform an action from the keyboard rather than use the mouse to choose a command from a menu or dialog. Each access key is identified by an underlined letter on a menu or dialog option.

Some &app; dialogs support the use of access keys. To specify the character to use as the access key, place an underscore before that character in the text of the dialog. The following example shows how to specify the letter 'C' as the access key:

sect2.para: All &app; dialogs support the following general options:

Specifies the icon that is displayed in the window frame of the dialog. There are 4 stock icons also available by providing the following keywords - 'info', 'warning', 'question' and 'error'.

sect2.title: Miscellaneous Options
sect2.para: &app; also provides the following miscellaneous options:

listitem.para: Displays the About &appname; dialog, which contains &app; version information, copyright information, and developer information.
Displays the version number of &app;.

sect2.title: GTK+ Options
sect2.para: &app; supports the standard GTK+ options. For more information about the GTK+ options, execute the matedialog -? command.

sect2.title: Environment Variables
sect2.para: Normally, &app; detects the terminal window from which it was launched and keeps itself above that window. This behavior can be disabled by unsetting the WINDOWID environment variable.

sect1.title: Calendar Dialog
sect1.para: Use the --calendar option to create a calendar dialog. &app; returns the selected date to standard output. If no date is specified on the command line, the dialog uses the current date.
The calendar dialog supports the following options:

listitem.para: Specifies the text that is displayed in the calendar dialog.
Specifies the day that is selected in the calendar dialog. day must be a number between 1 and 31 inclusive.
Specifies the month that is selected in the calendar dialog. month must be a number between 1 and 12 inclusive.
Specifies the year that is selected in the calendar dialog.

Specifies the format that is returned from the calendar dialog after date selection. The default format depends on your locale. format must be a format that is acceptable to the strftime function, for example %A %d/%m/%y.

sect1.title: File Selection Dialog
sect1.para: Use the --file-selection option to create a file selection dialog. &app; returns the selected files or directories to standard output. The default mode of the file selection dialog is open.
The file selection dialog supports the following options:

listitem.para: Specifies the file or directory that is selected in the file selection dialog when the dialog is first shown.
Allows the selection of multiple filenames in the file selection dialog.
Allows only selection of directories in the file selection dialog.
Set the file selection dialog into save mode.
Specifies the string that is used to divide the returned list of filenames.

sect1.title: Notification Icon

listitem.para: Specifies the text that is displayed in the notification area.

sect1.title: List Dialog
sect1.para: Use the --list option to create a list dialog. &app; returns the entries in the first column of text of selected rows to standard output.
Data for the dialog must specified column by column, row by row. Data can be provided to the dialog through standard input. Each entry must be separated by a newline character.
If you use the --checklist or --radiolist options, each row must start with either 'TRUE' or 'FALSE'.
The list dialog supports the following options:

listitem.para: Specifies the column headers that are displayed in the list dialog. You must specify a --column option for each column that you want to display in the dialog.
Specifies that the first column in the list dialog contains check boxes.
Specifies that the first column in the list dialog contains radio boxes.
Allows the displayed items to be edited.
Specifies what string is used when the list dialog returns the selected entries.
Specifies what column should be printed out upon selection. The default column is '1'. 'ALL' can be used to print out all columns in the list.

sect1.title: Message Dialogs
sect1.para: &app; can create four types of message dialog:

listitem.para: Error
Information
Question
Warning

sect1.para: For each type, use the --text option to specify the text that is displayed in the dialog.

sect2.title: Error Dialog
sect2.para: Use the --error option to create an error dialog.

sect2.title: Information Dialog
sect2.para: Use the --info option to create an information dialog.

sect2.title: Question Dialog
sect2.para: Use the --question option to create a question dialog.

sect2.title: Warning Dialog
sect2.para: Use the --warning option to create a warning dialog.

sect1.title: Progress Dialog
sect1.para: Use the --progress option to create a progress dialog.

&app; reads data from standard input line by line. If a line is prefixed with #, the text is updated with the text on that line. If a line contains only a number, the percentage is updated with that number.
The progress dialog supports the following options:

listitem.para: Specifies the text that is displayed in the progress dialog.
Specifies the initial percentage that is set in the progress dialog.
Closes the progress dialog when 100% has been reached.
Specifies that the progress bar pulsates until an EOF character is read from standard input.

sect1.title: Text Entry Dialog
sect1.para: Use the --entry option to create a text entry dialog. &app; returns the contents of the text entry to standard output.
The text entry dialog supports the following options:

listitem.para: Specifies the text that is displayed in the text entry dialog.
Specifies the text that is displayed in the entry field of the text entry dialog.
Hides the text in the entry field of the text entry dialog.

sect1.title: Text Information Dialog
sect1.para: Use the --text-info option to create a text information dialog.
The text information dialog supports the following options:

listitem.para: Specifies a file that is loaded in the text information dialog.
Allows the displayed text to be edited. The edited text is returned to standard output when the dialog is closed.

sect1.para:
The following example script shows how to create a text information dialog:
#!/bin/sh
FILE=`matedialog --file-selection \ --title="Select a File"`
case $? in 0) matedialog --text-info \ --title=$FILE \ --filename=$FILE \ --editable 2>/tmp/tmp.txt;; 1) echo "No file selected.";; -1) echo "No file selected.";; esac
